images.copyright: Christmas trees in Old Quebec (© Jean Surprenant/Getty Images)
images.title: Christmas couture
images.caption: Merry Christmas!
images.desc: Under a crisp Canadian winter sky, it's the glow of Christmas trees—on city squares, on neighbourhood lawns and in living-room windows—that sets the season alight. From Toronto's Cavalcade of Lights to Vancouver's Festival of Lights at VanDusen Garden, communities gather around these lit evergreens, sharing warmth during the year's coldest weeks. Christmas—a celebration of faith, light and togetherness—invites people to bring that brightness indoors. Garlands wind through hallways, candles cast a soft glow across familiar rooms and mistletoe hangs in doorways while wreaths greet guests at the front door.

og.title: Merry Christmas!

images.copyright: Snowy chapel with Christmas tree in the Bavarian Alps, Germany (© mauritius images GmbH/Alamy)
images.title: Traditions that travel
images.caption: Christmas Eve
images.desc: As Christmas Eve arrives, millions embrace customs that connect us to our roots—or introduce us to entirely new cultures. In snowy regions like the Bavarian Alps in Germany—a frost-kissed landscape seen in today's image—festive lights glow against winter's chill. Elsewhere, the sun blazes brightly: think of the Caribbean, Australia or Brazil, where Christmas often means golden beaches instead of frosty mornings.

og.desc: As Christmas Eve arrives, millions embrace customs that connect us to our roots—or introduce us to entirely new cultures. In snowy regions…

images.copyright: Reindeer during winter snowfall, Lapland, Finland (© Roberto Moiola/Getty Images)
images.title: Where holiday magic runs on hooves
images.caption: Reindeer, Lapland, Finland
images.desc: Few creatures evoke the magic of the holidays quite like the reindeer. Also known as caribou, they are the spirit animals of Christmas lovers—and they rock it. Sturdy and sure-footed, they've been pulling Santa's sleigh ever since Clement Clarke Moore cast them in the role in his 1823 poem 'A Visit from Saint Nicholas.' And they were born for it. Their hooves shrink in winter to expose a gripping rim, then expand in warmer months for better traction.
images.bsTitle: Where holiday magic runs on hooves

images.copyright: 'The Nutcracker' performed by the Turkish State Opera and Ballet in Ankara, Türkiye (© Anadolu/Getty Images)
images.title: From Hoffmann's pages to global stages
images.caption: 'The Nutcracker' performed by the Turkish State Opera and Ballet in Türkiye
images.desc: As Christmas approaches across Canada, each sunset gives way to a soft glow of festive lights—from window candles in Toronto homes to snowy displays in prairie towns—bringing a touch of wonder and preparing us for the holiday season. One of the world's most beloved stage works, 'The Nutcracker,' is rooted in this very sense of magic. The story unfolds on Christmas Eve, when Clara receives a nutcracker as a gift. As night falls and the household drifts into sleep, the girl and her nutcracker embark on a fantastical journey—battling the Mouse King and wandering through the Land of Sweets. Among its most famous moments is the dance of the Sugar Plum Fairy, accompanied by music that has become iconic.
images.bsTitle: From Hoffmann's pages to global stages

images.copyright: Dawn light through frosty trees, Sweden (© Schon/Getty Images)
images.title: Birth of the new sun
images.caption: Winter solstice
images.desc: Ever felt as if the night just wouldn't end? That's the winter solstice working its magic. It is the shortest day and longest night of the year in the Northern Hemisphere, occurring around December 21 or 22. In the Southern Hemisphere, the same happens around June 21 or 22. It marks the moment when one of Earth's poles tilts farthest from the sun. From that instant, daylight slowly begins to lengthen again.

images.copyright: Paper Christmas star lanterns, Germany (© artas/Getty Images)
images.title: Twinkle, twinkle, paper stars
images.caption: Christmas star lanterns, Germany
images.desc: As Christmas draws near, star lanterns begin to appear everywhere—twinkling from balconies, shining in shop windows and lighting up market stalls. Their shimmer cuts through the long winter nights, filling streets and homes with joy, colour and a sense of togetherness. But behind these festive decorations lies a story as captivating as their glow.

images.copyright: Snow-covered landscape at Bormio, Lombardy, Italy (© Roberto Moiola/Getty Images)
images.title: High mountains, deep history
images.caption: Bormio, Lombardy, Italy
images.desc: Bormio is a mountain town in northern Italy's Lombardy region, nestled in the Alps near the Stelvio Pass. This location has connected communities across mountain valleys for centuries, shaping how people live and move through the region. Today's image features Bormio's winter landscape, a reflection of its high-altitude setting and enduring bond with the surrounding peaks.

images.copyright: Temple of the Sun, Capitol Reef National Park, Utah, United States (© Austin Cronnelly/TANDEM Stills + Motion)
images.title: Layers of time in Utah
images.caption: Capitol Reef National Park, Utah, United States
images.desc: Rock layers formed over millions of years and a massive bend in the Earth's crust give this desert a rare window into geologic history. This is Capitol Reef National Park in Utah, where sandstone cliffs and canyons preserve a striking record of the planet's past. Today's featured image highlights the sandstone monoliths of Cathedral Valley, including the Temple of the Sun, part of this extraordinary, protected landscape.
